Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Increasing energy capture in solar cells made using solar inks
Award.AbstractNarration:
A dramatic reduction in the cost of flexible, lightweight solar cells (photovoltaics) is needed for direct integration of solar cells with buildings, vehicles, and textiles to be commercially viable. Current solar cell fabrication methods utilize complex, high vacuum processing not readily compatible with flexible materials. Solar paints formulated from Copper Indium Gallium Selenide (CIGS) nanocrystals can be sprayed on most materials to create solar cells, offering a possible route to low cost photovoltaics. However, these devices convert a smaller percentage of the sunlight to electricity than needed for commercial viability. In collaboration with Dr. Lydia Wong of Nanyang Technological University (NTU), this project will investigate how to increase solar cell efficiency by forming a connected CIGS film by heating of the nanocrystals and selenium powder. The specialized equipment available at NTU will allow these experiments to be conducted.

Increased power conversion efficiency (PCE) in CIGS nanocrystal photovoltaics has been demonstrated by sintering the nanocrystal film in a selenium environment. Sintering of the nanocrystal grains increases the efficiency of the solar cell, but greater understanding is needed of the role of selenium in the growth process and device performance. Selenium partial pressure is difficult to control, but has significant impact on final film morphology and device performance. This study will systematically investigate the influence of selenium partial pressure on the sintered film characteristics and device PCE using a multizone furnace designed for CIGS photovoltaic fabrication. The proposed activity will explore the factors that increase the efficiency of CIGS nanocrystal photovoltaics as a path to developing ultra-low cost solar cells to fill the unmet need for flexible, light-weight solar power. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Copper Indium Gallium Selenide (CIGS) nanocrystals can be formulated into a solar paint and then spray deposited to fabricate solar cells on almost any material. CIGS solar paint could potentially lower the cost of photovoltaics, making solar energy more readily available. To date, the amount of sunlight converted to energy, or power conversion efficiency (PCE), of these devices has been limited. The PCE in CIGS nanocrystal photovoltaics can be increased by annealing the nanocrystal film in a selenium environment, sintering the nanocrystals and reducing charge recombination. However, the selenization process is difficult to control and small variations in selenium partial pressure have significant impact on final film morphology and device performance. To understand this process more fully, during EAPSI 2014 in Singapore I systematically controlled the selenium partial pressure independently of other process factors and studied the influence this had on the sintered film characteristics and device PCE. The work was carried out using a multizone furnace located at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. The major goal of this work was to explore the factors that increase the efficiency of CIGS nanocrystal photovoltaics as a path to developing ultra-low cost solar cells to fill the unmet need for flexible, light-weight solar power. An additional major goal was to provide training and professional development.

This research demonstrated the selenium partial pressure could be controlled by changing the selenium source temperature. The selenium source temperature had large influence on the nanocrystal grain growth and device performance. The primary outcome of the research was a clear relationship between the power conversion efficiency and the selenium source temperature.

This research opportunity in Singapore was a wonderful experience where I was able to learn new skills and experience a new culture. The experience has allowed me to more effectively continue research into making low cost solar a reality.
